children.name: have
children.definition: alsohave gotespecially UK  to be holding something or carrying it with you : có
examples: Excuse me, do you have change for a dollar?
Have you got a pen I could borrow?
I think you’ve got my tickets.
Have you got a match?
Look out! He’s got a gun.
have sth on/with you
Have you got any money on you?
I’m afraid I don’t have my address book with me.
have something on you/ˌhæv something ˈɒn juː/ [verb phrase not in progressive] to be carrying somethingin your pocket, bag etc: có cái gì trong túi, giỏ xách
▪ I don’t have enough change on me for the parking meter.
▪ Jim is the only guy I know who always has a handkerchief on him.
have something with you/ˌhæv something ˈwɪð juː/ [verb phrase not in progressive] to have something inyour pocket, bag, hand etc: có cái gì trong túi, giỏ xách
▪ Her address is in my diary but I haven’t got it with me.
▪ She had her camera with her on the hike.
▪ You should have your identity card with you at all times.
have/keep sth handyalsohave/keep sth to hand[adverb] to have something near you, especially because you might need to use it: có trong tầm tay
▪ When you call, have your credit card handy.
▪ Before you begin make sure you have all the tools you need to hand.
▪ Keep a fire extinguisher handy in the kitchen.
▪ Keep important telephone numbers to hand by the telephone.
have sth in your possession[VP not in progressive] formal to have sth in your hand, pocket, bag etc, especially something illegal: sở hữu trái phép
The man who was arrested had an illegal firearm in his possession.
The drugs he had in his possession had an estimated street value of $15,000.

children.name: with
children.definition: /wɪð, wɪθ/  someone with something has that thing now: sở hữu
examples: ▪ There’s a man at the door with a parcel for you.
▪ A woman with a baby in a stroller was looking at clothes.
▪ Rob is the guy with the blue jacket.

children.name: to have sth such as a television, car etc
own
children.definition: if you own sth, especially something big like a house, a car, or a company, it is your property and you have the legal right to have it: có , sở hữu
examples: We don’t own the apartment, we’re just renting it.
Clark owns about 40 companies in northern Europe.
The building is owned by the local council.
You need to get permission from the farmer who owns the land.
Many more people now own their own homes.
the cost of owning a car
publicly/privately ownedBritish English(= belonging to the government or a private organization )
a privately owned company
In National Parks, although the land is privately owned, there are strict controls on the use of the land.

children.name: with
children.definition: /wɪð, wɪθ/ someonewith something has that thing: có, sở hữu
examples: ▪ There aren’t many people with cars in this part of town -- they’re too poor.
▪ Taking the bus across the country appeals to people with more time than money.
▪ Anybody with shares in the company is urged to contact the receivers to register a claim.

children.name: have
children.definition: (alsohave gotespecially British English)spokento own sth – used when focussing on the fact that sb has the use of sth, rather than the fact that they legally own it :
examples: They used to have a Mercedes Benz.
Has your secretary got a fax machine?
Have you ever had your own business?
He’s a lovely dog – how long have you had him?
Can I have the car tonight, Dad?

children.name: possess
children.definition: formal to own something - use this especially in negative sentences to say that sb does not own sth that most people own: có ,sở hữu
examples: Very few families in this area possess a telephone
He never wore a suit - I don’t think he possessed one.
Because of his gambling, he lost everything he possessed.
Different workers possess different skills.
He no longer possessed the power to frighten her.
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually say that someonehasorhas gotsth rather thanpossessesit:
They allhavedifferent skills.

children.name: to have st that you do not want
be stuck with
children.definition: /biː ˈstʌk wɪð/  mắc kẹt với
examples: ▪ It’s only a rented house, so we’re stuck with the decor.
▪ As a result of the financial collapse many people are stuck with worthless investments.

children.name: to have a particular feature, quality, or ability
have
children.definition: alsohave gotespecially UK  used to say what someone or something looks like, what qualities or features they possess etc :
examples: She has dark hair and brown eyes.
Sullivan’s music does have a certain charm.
You need to have a lot of patience to be a teacher.
Wild rice has a very nutty flavour.
He didn’t even have the courtesy to answer my letter.
have it in you(= have the skill or special quality needed to do something )
You should have seen the way Dad was dancing – I didn’t know he had it in him!
RegisterIn everyday British English, people usually sayhave got sthrather thanhave sth,but in writing they usually prefer to use justhave:
He’s gota degree from Bristol University. (spoken, everyday)
He hasall the relevant qualifications. (written)

children.name: with
children.definition: /wɪð, wɪθ/  use this after a noun to describe the qualities or features that someone or something has: bằng
examples: ▪ We booked a room with a sea view.
▪ The company needs more people with marketing experience.
▪ Katrina’s over there in front of that man with red hair.

children.name: there be U
children.definition: there is/there are/ðeər ɪz, ðeər ɑːʳ/ use this to describe the things that a place has: có
examples: ▪ It’s a big house - there are five bedrooms.
▪ There are lots of old temples and gardens to visit in Kyoto.
▪ There’s an Olympic-sized swimming pool on campus.

children.name: possess
children.definition: formal to have a particular ability, feature, or quality: sở hữu
examples: ▪ He possessed an unusual ability to learn languages quickly.
▪ Like all towns and villages on Trinidad, it possessed a cricket ground.
▪ The Western Highlands possess a beauty and a majesty found nowhere else in Britain.

children.name: of U
children.definition: of especially written if someone or something is of a particular feature, quality, or ability, they have that feature etc, especially if it is something good: của
examples: ▪ Father was a man of great integrity and honesty.
▪ an area of outstanding beauty
▪ She was an actress of great skill.

children.name: enjoy
children.definition: formal to have special advantages, conditions, abilities etc that are better than the ones that other people or things have: có được, hưởng được
examples: Some of the workers enjoy a relatively high degree of job security.
When first introduced on the market, these products enjoyed great success.
Even though he's 86, he enjoys excellent health.

children.name: be blessed with
children.definition: /biː ˈblest wɪð/  to have something such as a useful ability, a good feature, or an important advantage - used formally or humorously: thừa hưởng
examples: ▪ Londoners are blessed with some of the very best Thai restaurants in the country.
▪ Justine was unfortunately not blessed with a sense of humour.
▪ Few gardens are blessed with an ideal site.

children.name: be endowed with
children.definition: /biː ɪnˈdaʊd wɪð/  formal to have something good, especially a natural ability or social advantage: trời phú
examples: ▪ Hugh was young, handsome, and endowed with the privileges of class and education.
▪ Jefferson wrote that all citizens were endowed with ‘the rights to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness.’

children.name: boast
children.definition: if something such as a place, organization, or object boasts a good feature, it has that feature - used especially in advertisements and literature: “lấy làm kiêu hãnh về”
examples: The golf course is surrounded by hills and boasts some of the finest scenery in the country.
Each luxury home boasts an indoor pool and three-car garage.
The city boasts two excellent museums.
The Society boasts 3,000 members worldwide.

children.name: be mine
children.definition: /yours/John’s etc if something is mine/yours/John’s etc, it belongs to me, you, John etc: của tôi/bạn/John
examples: ▪ ‘Hey, that’s my pen!’ - ‘Sorry! I didn’t know it was yours.’
▪ ‘Whose bike is that?’ ‘It’s Martin’s.’

children.name: belong to
children.definition: if sth belongs to sb, they own it: thuộc về
examples: This watch belonged to my grandfather.
A car believed to belong to the bank robbers was found abandoned yesterday
The ring belonged to my grandmother.

children.name: own
children.definition: your /jɔːr ˈəʊn/  belonging to you and not to anyone else: cho riêng bạn
examples: ▪ You can rent skis or you can bring your own.
▪ Joe left the company to set up his own business.
of your own/əv jɔːr ˈəʊn/ [adjective phrase]a room/car/computer etc of your ownone that belongs to you and no one else, especially when this is something you want to own: sở hữu của
▪ Our neighbours let us use their garage, but we really need one of our own.
▪ The charity provides accommodation for homeless people, and helps them find homes of their own.

children.name: be the property of
children.definition: formal to belong to sb - often written on books, clothes etc to show who owns them:
examples: This hymn book is the property of Pitt Street Methodist Church.
If he defaults on the loan, the land will become the property of the bank.
This camera is the property of the BBC.

children.name: my
children.definition: /your/his etc/maɪ, jɔːʳ, hɪz/  belonging to me, you, him etc:
examples: ▪ Please can you move your car? It’s blocking my driveway.
▪ I’ve got a problem with my dishwasher.
▪ My grandmother lives near your place -- just around the corner in fact.

children.name: personal
children.definition: belonging only to you - used especially in official contexts: thuộc về cá nhân
examples: sb’s personal possessions/property/belongings
The dead man’s personal possessions were sent back to his family.
my/their etc own personal cá nhân
You can arm and disarm the alarm system using your own personal access code.

children.name: to say you have a right to be the legal owner or sth
lay claim to
children.definition: to say that you have a right to own sth, especially sth that is owned by sb else: tuyên bố chủ quyền, tuyên bố quyền sở hữu
examples: Both Britain and Argentina lay claim to the Falkland Islands.
A stranger who said he was my father’s brother had arrived to lay claim to his fortune.

children.name: stake your claim
children.definition: to say publicly that you believe you have a right to own sth, especially when other people also say they have a right to own it: tuyên bố quyền sở hữu
examples: If you want some of the furniture, now’s the time to stake your claim.

children.name: of
children.definition: prepositionPOSSESSION
examples: used to show possession, belonging or origin
a friend of mine
the president of the United States
employees of the company
the colour of his hair
a habit of mine
that revolting dog of hers
the love of a good woman
the complete plays of (= written by) Federico Garcia Lorca

children.name: possession
children.definition: formalif something is in your possession, you own it, or you have obtained it from somewhere : sở hữu
examples: in sb’s possession
The house has been in the family’s possession since the 1500s.
That information is not in our possession.
in possession of something
She was found in possession of stolen goods.
How did the paintingcome intoyourpossession(= how did you get it )?
The finance company nowhas possession ofthe house.
We didn’ttake possession of(= get and start using )the car until a few days after the auction.
be in somebody's possessionThe painting has been in the family's possession since then.
come into somebody's possessionYou have a duty not to disclose confidential information that comes into your possession.
be in possession of something(= have it )Before applying for a job, make sure you are in possession of the required qualifications.
have something in your possession(= have it )My father had in his possession a letter written by Winston Churchill.
come into possession of something(= start having it )How did you come into possession of this document?
take possession of something(= start having or using it )At 21, he was entitled to take possession of the property.

children.name: bear
children.definition: verbbore,borneorUS ALSObornKEEP
examples: 3. [ T ] to have or continue to have something
Their baby bearsastrongresemblance/an uncanny likeness toits grandfather.
The stone plaque bearing his name was smashed to pieces.
On display were boxing gloves which bore Rocky Marciano's signature.
[ + two objects ]I don't bear them any ill feeling (= I do not continue to be angry with or dislike them) .
Thank you for your advice, I'll bear itin mind(= will remember and consider it) .

children.name: have
children.definition: include/contain(alsohave gotespecially British English)  to include or contain something or a particular number of things or people :
examples: Japan has a population of over 120 million.
How many pages has it got?
have something in it/them
The tank still has water in it.

children.name: on
children.definition: prepositionPOSSESSION
examples: 21. [ before pronoun ] used to show when someone has something with them in their pocket or in a bag that they are carrying
Have you got a spare cigarette on you?
I haven't got my driving licence on me.

children.name: ownership
children.definition: the fact of owning something : sở hữu
examples: ownership of
a dispute over the ownership of the land
Do you have any proof of ownership of this car?
public/private/state ownership
The company was returned to private ownership in mid-1987.
The price ofhome ownershipis increasing.
Rates of home ownership have remained relatively constant.

children.name: carry
children.definition: verbHAVE WITH YOU
examples: 2. [ T ] to have something with you all the time
Police officers in Britain do not usually carry guns.
figurativeHe will carry thememoryof the accident with him (= will remember the accident) for ever.

children.name: hold
children.definition: to officially own or possess money, a document, a company etc :
examples: She works for Le Monde, where the staff hold a significant stake in the company.
a situation in which a husband and wife both hold shares in a family company
One man holds a third of the company’s shares.
He holds shares in ICI.
Do you hold a valid passport?
aprivately heldcompany
holding[C]
Mr Davis has a 30% holding in owns 30% of Montague Enterprises.

children.name: hold
children.definition: job/title
examples: a)to have a particular job or position, especially an important one :
Do you really think he’s capable of holding such a responsible position?
hold the post/position/office etc (of something)
She was the first woman to hold the office of Australian state premier.
The governor had held the post since 1989.
Whoever is elected willhold office(= have an important political position )for four years.
b)to have a particular title or record, because you have won a competition, are the best at something etc :
The programme stillholds the record forthe longest running TV series.
The last Briton to hold the title was Bert Nicholson.

children.name: hold
children.definition: in your hand/arms
examples: a)[ transitive ] to have something in your hand, hands, or arms :
Could you hold my bag for me?
hold something in your hand/arms
He was holding a knife in one hand.
I held the baby in my arms.
hold hands(= hold each other’s hands )
They sat holding hands under a tree.
hold somebody close/tightly(= with your arms around someone )
Max held her close and wiped away her tears.
b)[ transitive always + adverb/preposition ] to move your hand or something in your hand in a particular direction
hold something out/up etc
Heheld outhishandto help her to her feet.
Hold the picture up so we can see it.

children.name: control
children.definition: /have control of to own a larger part of a company than other people so that you have power to make decisions about that company: giành quyền kiểm soát
examples: As well as owning Mirror Group Newspapers, the Maxwell Corporation also controlled several other businesses.
The Johnson family has effective control of the company, owning almost 60% of the shares.

children.name: interest
children.definition: /ˈɪntrɪst, ˈɪntrəst/  if a person, company, or government has aninterestin a business, they own part of that business: lợi tức
examples: interest in
▪ The bank has interests in several companies, including a 15% share of Morgan’s Brewery.
controlling interesta large enough part of the company or business to give you the power to make decisions about it
▪ Although the government has made some shares in National Oil Products available, it intends to maintain its controlling interest.

children.name: have a stake in
children.definition: to own part of a company and therefore be able to have a share in the money it makes: nắm giữ cổ phần
examples: ▪ Labatt beer has a 45% stake in the Blue Jays baseball team.
▪ She has a stake in her husband’s company, which she will have to give up if they divorce.
